It is easy to fall in love (or we think we fall in love) with someone eager and charming because we are usually befuddled by gorgeous appearance. Human beings are kind of weird, always purchase what we do not have and only perceive the value of something when we lost it (or nearly lost it).
I just want to send this message to my unborn daughter (OMG, have I gone nut? Seriously I send it to myself). There might be plenty of guys in your whole life can drive you crazy and make your heart beats fast, but do not move so fast, do not let those flatterers cloud your eyes. He may deceive you about the idea following your heart, but I dare say that you are better follow both your heart and mind since we cannot live using hearts only. There are too many obstacles ahead waiting for you, life must not be easy like the way you think it is when you was 17!. So, whenever you hesitate, ask yourself and look deeply into your heart, who are the one always there for you? Who are always next to you when your fail and get lost? If you have that one, you are a lucky girl.

Continuing to be a romantic love story under the delicate pen of Nguyen Nhat Anh.
He not only wrote stories for children but also for adults who were once lacking in children and still had a young soul. Reading books were written by Nguyen Nhat Anh always makes me gobble from the first chapter to the last chapter to understand the stories, to satisfy and to absorb what he created there. Describing a triangle love with the deep sympathy of Vinh, who always dedicates his love to the heroine named Mien.
"An award of love is itself", everyone wants to have a beautiful love and the ending he brings us a profound result: the sacrifice of Vinh was make up for him by loving of Mien.
So guys, please read right now and discover the emotional levels in "Once upon a time there was a love story".

I'm 24, but this book or the others from Nguyen Nhat Anh are always brought me back to those days of childhood.
How can I say! a hard poor childhood time at a rural country in the middle of Viet Nam helps me to be any of guys (characters)- who were teenagers and the author brought into his book naturally. I felt I was on that guava branch in the "burning" afternoon, felt so fresh on that bike when behind my back was "my crush", felt again any night without sleep because missing "crush" and a bunch of "crazy thought" (could be silly ones)
Be an adult is harder than everyone was thinking about this before. The older you are the more responsibilities you need to carry on your shoulder. Sometimes, you can be alone but, even you dunt know why?
But, pls back to these old days again by Nguyen Nhat Anh's books. He'an adult which a special mind, he can be older by looking but his mind is always 15 years old.

Continuing is a story about the childhood period.
Still the gentle, clear tone of the voice, gave me some unforgettable emotional circuits of this story. Thinking about childhood with so many mischievous games and careless teenage love.
In addition, there are four poems written by Nguyen Nhat Anh in this book, which increase the attractiveness and interest, making me want to read quickly to discover this book.
So welcome to you to read and feel the sweetness of love, the careless of adolescence and boys are doing all sorts of ways to get the attention of the girls those who they like in "Seven Steps To The Summer ".

I have such an amazing time reading this book. Way too funny for my heart to handle, hehe. Writing about kids and their interactions in a small village is such a strong suit for the author and I hope he will continue writing about this topic. Definitely a memorable book and I will keep coming back to this book for a good laughter.

The story is told about characters those who are primary and secondary school friends in Ha Lam town.
Throughout the content of the story is a beautiful love affair between Tham and Dang. With a soft tone of voice, it draws me into innocent school-age love stories to later become an extremely sincere affection.
Every time I read Nguyen Nhat Anh's books, I have to read them seamlessly to satisfy the curiosity that he will lead me to all parts of the country, taking me to life stories and cute thoughts of teenager.
Welcome you to read and feel not to know whether to laugh or cry, the lovely difficulties of a love story in "Young banana tree wears green shoes".

Nguyen Nhat Anh has said about this book that he did not write this book for children, but instead he wrote it to those who used to be children. And indeed as I flipped between the pages in this book, it was as though there is this voice who's speaking to the Inner Child inside my mind. Indeed, Inner Child has been one of the most interesting research topics in popular psychology. The term Inner Child corresponds to individual childlike's aspects that keep embodying our minds even as we grow older in life and it includes what each of us has learned in childhood before we hit puberty. It is often conceived as a semi-independent sub-personality that is subordinate to our conscious minds.
This book is indeed tries to provoke our Inner Childs through the perspective of a 40-years-old adult who recalled the memories from when he was 8 years old. It began with a simple notion that hit most of us into actions: boredom. As a child, he embraced the notion of boredom by doing many things from asking endless "why" questions to his parents into sending text message "Shall we get into bed this evening? I'm so very sad!" with childlike purity. I find myself laughing as it began to dawn on me how we slowly find this childlike wonders about many things in life started to disappear from us as soon as we reached adulthood when social conformity is the value that is regarded highly in our society.
Just like what the title promised, this book is indeed a ticket to childhood. Albeit each of us experienced childhood differently, there might be some ways we could relate to what Nguyen Nhat Anh wrote in this book. Even though I read the English translation, I could feel the charm of childhood portrayals in this book. As like in every childhood groups, there will always be perpetrators, followers and the adults who will spank the children. There are many ways to philosophise the way the main character in this book thinks, in the way that could shed light to most adults on how they could better treat children.

The frequent contrasting between childhood and adulthood made by the author is reminiscent of the famous French work "The Little Prince" and the Japanese novel "Totto-chan".
The main differences is that these stories told by Mui take place in our actual world (instead of a fantasy world) and are based in Vietnam. I even suspect that the meta-story of how Mui recounts his own childhood from his 40-year-old self is merely a semi-autobiographical account by the actual author himself.
Anyway, this novel is truly a pleasant ride to the mindset of a child that is aimed for adult readers. As the spine synopsis says, "even if [the author Nguyen Nhat Anh] can't transport us back to our own past, [this book] gives us the next best thing".

Just the sweetest. This is a fast and enjoyable read and truly blurs the line between fiction and biography. This should be required reading for grown ups; it is impossible to read this without recollecting the forgotten magic of childhood and the anguish of having to grow up and away from innocence.

I had a good five minute long internal debate with myself before reviewing this book because I read the translated work (the book is originally in Vietnamese) and I have mixed feelings about the book.
I wonder if the reason I didn't enjoy the book is because of the content or because of how the original content was translated.
With The Man with Compound Eyes, translation seemed pretty on point, with of course, some liberty taken for the sake of cohesion...
Of course, I know Mandarin much better than I know Vietnamese, and when reading this book, I could only translate the little bits I could into Vietnamese. So I can't speak for the accuracy of translation for both the words and the culture...
But with this book it seemed slightly disjointed at parts yet absolutely charming in others.
While I knew the book was written as sort of a musing or meanderings of a man's reflection about childhood, and hence expected some episodic writing, the book seemed really REALLY too incoherent at some parts. I wonder if it's because, as I've read in some reviews elsewhere, that the translated version removed and added some parts.
Well, whatever it is, I guess I'll only find out if and when I read the original Vietnamese book. That may take awhile because my proficiency in Vietnamese language could probably be likened to that of a five year old.

I read this book in Vietnamese about five or six years back, when I first came to the U.S. I remember bringing this book from Vietnam as a gift from my cousin, whom I refer to as sister. This is a very lovely book from Nguyá»…n Nháº­t Ãnh; he captures the easy-going, and exciting life of many Vietnamese children very well, and of course, this book was not written for children, rather, it was for adults who want a ticket back to their childhoods, a trip down the memory lane. This book serves that purpose very well; it is fast-paced, easy to read, lighthearted. The tone is distinctly that of the South, very down-to-earth, full-of-live, immensely innocent, but unfortunately, all of this, including the quirkiness, got lost during translation. I don't get the same fondness feeling when I read the English the version. But that doesn't mean it is not good, people!

I almost returned this to the library unread since I'm trying to read my own books, but I'm glad I didn't. It's a short little book, only about 140 pages, but it did a great job at capturing childhood, or more clearly, an adult's memory of childhood. I liked seeing how someone growing up across the world from me could have similar childhood memories. It reads like a memoir and felt very real, even though it's a novel (or is it?). It made me think about all of my memories of playing with the kids in the neighborhood and all the games we would come up with.
This was almost a 4-star read, but I switched it to 3 stars due to the last chapter, which had sad animal stuff. :( It wasn't graphic, so don't let that steer you away, but people in Vietnam view dogs differently than we do here in the U.S. - I'll leave it at that.

A very enjoyable slice of childhood. A short read, the author recounts various episodes of his time growing up in Vietnam. This is in the same style as another very good book called "Totto-chan: The girl in the Window" (life in Japan as a child). It is a pleasant recollection of a childhood adventures that reminded me of Mark Twain's writing.
The author breaks the barrier between himself as a character and himself as an author with an occasional wink to his reader. He also does a good job in pointing out the differences between the child and adult mind.
This is not a Vietnam War story in any way. After visiting Vietnam on business I became fascinated by the country and am always eager to read about its people and culture in a context other than either the Vietnam-American War of the Indochina War.

There's is eloquence in simplicity, it is sometimes said, and I found that to be the case with this novel. It is a short but impactful recall to the creativity and enthusiastic wonder that defines childhood and contrasts the abundant monotony of adulthood.
I finished this book in between 2-3 hours and loved any bit of it. How relieving it felt after the weeks I've spent reading huge, 500+ page volumes filled to the brim with blandness.
Moreover, I commend the author for being able to capture the tone of child-like innocence in his prose. As a writer myself, I understand that personalized voice is a very difficult characteristic to imitate, and I was impressed with his authenticity in style. Kudos to him!

A short and sweet trip down memory lane. I didn't enjoy it so much in the beginning despite the beautiful first paragraph, as I thought the stories were hit and miss alternatively, but it got better in the later chapters. Now I'm missing my childhood friends and wondering where they are today! I hope they're all safe and healthy and happy.
I love the subject matter, the innocence of childhood and growing up in Vietnam. It's a bit rare to find bestselling novels from Asia that aren't about poverty or colonialism or the horrors of war or living under some despotic regime or somat.
I wish there were more books like this from Southeast Asian countries translated into English, so that I and more people can read them, because Asian lives are so much more than the stereotypical depictions found in Hollywood movies or western media. Millions of us Asians have normal lives and normal concerns and normal struggles, you know? Normal stories that are also beautiful in their own ways and deserve to be recorded on paper.

A long story of Nguyen Nhat Anh takes us through all the joyful and innocent emotions of 4 cute little kids who always want to do all naughty things: Mui, Hai, Tun and Ti. Through his clear, witty voice, he led us to visit his own childhood memories, giving the reader an innocent time of the children but he inserted in it the adult pangs.
Reading "Give me a ticket to childhood" make me feel a beautiful, carefree childhood play with all the monstrosities, like looking back at some memories of our childhood. This book is like a ticket for those who wish to return to the time of taking a rain, joyful. I hope you to read and feel what he brought a circuit of the climax of emotion when we were little throughout the book "Give me a ticket to childhood"!

But you can, without a ticket, revisit your childhood any time. Just step out of the shallow man=made canal and into deep water. p155
TNA may be having us on here, as he considers possibilities for framing this story of innocence and inevitability. Is this memoir, documentary fiction, or fantasy? Can our memories redeem themselves? Can we ever redeem our memories?
I've discovered that one mans boring rut is another mans domestic harmony. p28
Whatever the case, TNA gives us the observations of a father as he recalls himself at the age of eight. Taking the reader into his confidence, he radiates mischief and goodwill. The transitions between points of view, the wise child and the man he has become, are seamless.
But the decks are always stacked, and you know how. p120
For such a short book, a lot is covered. With eloquence, wit and style, ,TNA takes us right back into the heart of the mystery.
All children are poets, who hear the music and see the colors of the letters on the page=magic portals to a wilderness without fixed meanings, where intuition shows you the way. All that adults see are neat rows of black lines.....p130
There are lots of intelligent people in the world, and lots of honest people . As a rule, the super=smart ones are glib and self serving, while the congenitally honest tend to be simple=minded. What a pity for civilization! p108
Old wars ended and new wars began, children still went to bed hungry. p83
But don't get the impression that this is a bleak little book or a morality tale tarted up for modern sensibilities. The year of being eight had unexpected repercussions, and readers may find themselves wildly snickering at the capers of this little gang of four as they attempt to figure out
a way to negotiate the tricky world.

This little book was written by a Vietnamese author, and is a quaint story about his childhood. Each chapter could almost be read individually, like a short story.

This is a very simple book that I read in one sitting, it was short and sweet like the childhood which the author talks about. It makes one think of all the things we enjoyed as a child and what we lost as we grew. It makes us take a look at all the conformities that come with "being an adult." This book is translated and may not have as great of an effect as it would if you knew the Vietnamese language and culture, however it's message is still read loud and clear across all cultures.

While on my travels to Vietnam, I wanted to read a book written by an author based in the country. Walking into a bookstore, I found this gem.
It is written with the simplicity such that a child can understand and yet the profoundness that could leave adults with many questions. The theme is rooted in the spirit of being vs becoming - how innocence, openness, curiosity get crushed at the hands of conformance.
I only wish the author had left the key messages to the readers' imagination than explicitly explain some of them.

I had read the Vietnamese version of this book about 6-7 years ago and really liked it. I had tried to read it (the Vietnamese one, still) several times last year and found it somehow not as interesting as I had thought it was back then.
Then I happened to read this book recently - the English version - and loved it. William Naythons did a great job translating and made the writing style of Nguyen Nhat Anh much much more bearable and funny in an English way. The book itself was crazily expensive compared to its original, but it was definitely worth it.

I read this on my flight to Vietnam, along with a few other books, to get a better sense of Vietnamese culture. It was certainly interesting for that. Overall, I thought it was cute but can't say I loved it or was blown away by it. Definitely cute though.

a lot of good insight on kids point of view, or at least a grown ups perspective on what a kids point of view might be. funny, poetic, and sometimes annoying.
i liked this part best: Consult a dictionary if you want to know the meaning of adult life. Clothes cover our nakedness. Chairs are things to sit on.You eat at a table. you sleep in a bed. ... But children possess an invaluable treasure-their power to imagine the world differently, and to assign strange new functions to familiar things.
not sure why. maybe because i get so frustrated with my kids for doing this exact thing. chill out dad.

spoiled in places by too much preciousness and explication, i still love this book for what it accomplishes in its unique examination of the childhood brain. i also found myself mesmerized by some of the phrasing, much of it wrought through a simple but skilled wielding of the colon and semicolon. the book walks the tightrope with its metafictional qualities: sometimes an apparent fall turns into a brilliant and moving trick, but other times it fails to rescue itself.
i am fond of the hardback copy, at least, in its own performance art in recalling childhood: a very short novel, it desperately expands itself to the required 154 pages by beginning its numbering at the first title page, selecting an inflated typeface, and inserting blank pages between chapters. in context of the text, it works beautifully.

This book is about some stories that everybody has experienced once in their lives when they were young. These stories are really close to each person's life. But I don't like it very much because it has some romantic details which I hate :">

Is this really a novel, or a memoir masquerading as a novel? I'm not sure...but I did enjoy the experience. In its exploration of childhood, reflected in the eyes of adults, it's sweet, outrageous, funny, and poignant. It treats the fourth wall between writer and reader like a permeable membrane, and the end result is something slightly kooky and off-centre, but joyously entertaining.

Reading Äáº£o MÃ´ng MÆ¡ to me is like travelling back in time, right to the heart of my childhood. I clearly remember days when I and my best friend would pretend that we were magical creatures descending from heaven - our specialty includes telepathic communication, power to wind away other human beings, and split spirits from bodies. I remember playing "lost in a little island" with myself, trying to gather as much food for survival as I can. I remember vivid and serious conversations about those imaginary scenes with my friends. All of us would treat those fantasies with such seriousness and conviction! That is the reason why to this day, any story along the theme of surviving in a deserted island with limited resources still guarantees to win my heart.
I adore the simplistic and minimalistic writing of the book, I also love the illustrations that make the writing all the better. Sometimes, what one needs is not sophisticated, multi-layered storytelling, but storytelling that speaks directly to that special place in one's heart. This story does just that, for me.

Well, this is easily his most forgettable book. After the massive success of "I see yellow flower on green grass", who would have thought he would break the market with something like this, a book about dog ??? Thank god I didn't buy this book. Don't get me wrong, writing about dog is still okay as long as it is still original and thought-provoking (like some other works of his). "I am Beto" is 10 times better than this in terms of those criteria. I personally think this book failed me, but number-wise, it is a massive success with over 100.000 copies printed in the first place.
Why i still gave it 4 stars? Based solely on my enjoyment level, there were some seriously funny scenes and I broke out laughing. I don't think those funny moments will last long in my head, but I have a good time, so I don't want to be so harsh with the rating

It's about 5 dogs in a family. Each of them has different features and personalities.
Suku is a lovely boy with naive eyes that knock out human's heart immediately. But he has a bad habit that is beating people uncontrollably, even someone who strokes him.
Haili is a beautiful lady who really likes power in their house. She wants to occupy the important position by snatching Suku's bone and makes him go away. Therefore, other dogs scared of her, except Eme.
Eme is undaunted and she doesnt want to be controlled by anyone although she is so young. So she fights with Haili and people have to prevent them hard.
Pig is a hunting dog but she is really good-natured. She has a skill that is gnawing one's throat but she just uses it when joking with her friends. Especially, she can find out who is bad guest and barks continuously to warn her owner.
But they have the same feature that is loyalty, forever. Betrayal doesnt exist in their dictionary.
Someone said that: If you treat a dog like a human, it will treat you like a dog.

The story recalls me of my childhood when my life - like any other kids - revolved around my imagination. The world in a child's mind is so magical and beautiful and this book described it excellently. A lovely, nostalgic story with slightly dramatic events to aware people of today's issues (bullying, drugs, etc.) The book reminds adults to care for their children's lives and happiness and to let go of reality a bit. Really well-written.

The book is a gift from my high school teacher. Reading through the book gives me a feeling like I am reading a diary because the content of the book is composed of comments and experience of the author which was published in the previous newspapers. The content is not very special, this book make me feel like I am referring to the author's point of view on certain issues. Thanks to that, I have a different view on the literary works and the culture of my country - Vietnam, with some macro issues that the author mentioned.

The book really gives the reader a happy atmosphere, filled with laughter.
So welcome to you to read and admire the strange thing when animals talk to people with creative language in "Have a nice day".

The book is about Teo, who was unlucky in a terrible accident caused a spinal injury and after surgery he suffered from a sequelae that had to lie in one place. The story revolves around children who are innocent, playful and always a strong spiritual support for Teo, do everything for him, teach him,... Through this story, I see whether Teo must lie in a position spot, unable to run and play but he still showed us optimism, feeling himself lucky in an unlucky situation. Like many other books of Nguyen Nhat Anh, he always wrote for children but the words, lessons, messages send to everyone. When I reading the book "Making friends with the sky" make me feel the love, covering Teo of the relatives around him and he was also his brainchild when the author spent 7, 8 months to write this work. ** spoiler alert ** The last part complete threw me off, I couldn't believe it can turn out that way. The book was hillarious with variety of jokes and others but also made me felt anxious because I just can't wait to know what's about to happen next. One little minus point for this book is it has been inspired so much from Harry Potter, but still an amazing read from a Vietnamese author

A great great great series for teenager (adults can read too).
Have to admit that, yes, this series is strongly inspired by Harry Potter, but through the hand, the mind and the unique humor of Nguyen Nhat Anh, it has turned into something completely different.
Harry Potter describes a complex world with complex details, while this series describes a world full of colors, full of creativities with many twists and turns, added with teenage love, feelings and thinkings. Everyone can find a part of their teen-hood here. The whole series is written with such close and familiar materials it gets into not just our mind but our heart also. Such a masterpiece.
Whoever still doubts about the quality of the series, please give it a try. You won't regret. And don't look for the similarity to Harry Potter, look for the difference and the creativity. Have fun!

A long story of Nguyen Nhat Anh tells the story of a boy named Thu who used to be proud of himself as an intelligent, misleading and bully another girl, but now when he grows up, he always miserable to find himself stupid because he is henpecked by another girl. Then the "irony" until he meets Viet An again, the girl who confused him back then was Tieu Li, who used to suffer his mischief. Through the attractive voice and narration of the writer Nguyen Nhat Anh, we passionately watched the predestined when Tieu Li had to move to another place, leaving Thu to look forward and gossips from they was a kid to now they grow up.
When I finished reading "The girl who came from yesterday", I was filled with happiness and joy because life always has miracles called fate, so please believe that you meet in the world not a coincidence, they are passing our life for a reason!

Just read it to be ready for the upcoming movie :)). Couldnâ€™t undertand why people like it so much. Ha Lan is questionable, Ngan is quite romantically dumb, and poor Tra Long, her whole existence is just a replacement. The eye is not well described so i couldnâ€™t imagine how beautiful it was. The writing style is simple and easy to read but could not trigger much feelings nor imagination.

People love it because it's realistic. A good novel doesn't always have to have perfect characters. If you like perfect characters that much, you should read "The Notebook". Yes, Ngáº¡n sounds like a loser, HÃ  Lan must be a utilitarian girl, DÅ©ng is an f-boy. But that's why this story could have touched so many people- because it's realistic and it's relatable. We don't need to be Olympian Gods to love, to hate, to have meaningful memories and bitter experiences. Ngáº¡n, as I said- is just a below-average guy, but his loyalty with Ha Lan can be seen as the symbol for a type of love that so many people on earth have experienced: the innocent, no self-interest emotions toward your crush, your first love. Sometimes this type of love is harmful to both of the parties, but it's love regardless and that's why Ngáº¡n's emotion toward HÃ  Lan in this novel should be seen with empathy even if it's not rational at all.
HÃ  Lan can be observed as a typical beautiful girl who changed her environment from rural to urban. By choices, she could drive her life into some very different directions - she could either become independent and be happy, or her fate could also be very painful and miserable. Nguyá»…n Nháº­t Ãnh made her make a choice and we should not criticise it, but to learn from her decision's consequences. Furthermore- About DÅ©ng, I don't think he's that bad. Yeah, he's pretty bad, but in this novel, he represents the guys who are young, rich and have nothing to worry about in their whole life. Guys like that can be carefree, heartless or they can be seen by some people as cruel but it's a sad fact of life and there is little thing we can do about it other than protecting and improving ourselves. And lastly, TrÃ  Long- a cute girl with all the good traits, but turns out to be just an identical replacement of someone else. It's bitter and it's hard to accept, but then again it's realistic. Trust me, if you dive deep enough into love, someday you may find yourself- or your partner is just the replacement for a ghost of the past. But I hope that you all won't have to live your whole life in that miserable role, and that's what Nguyá»…n Nháº­t Ãnh are trying to say to us, by introducing the story of Ngáº¡n and TrÃ  Long.
So, did you see? "Máº¯t biáº¿c" is not a perfect love story, not even a good story. But it's a great novel about the love and the life of young Vietnamese people in the 60s (or 70s). The emotions in the novel are real, and I think that not only you and me, or people nowadays but also people in the future can feel related to it. Because it's love, and love is eternal.

I almost threw my Kindle across the room (lol) for the characters in the story angered me. But that also meant it was a great book, as it was capable of evoking emotions from readers. I think it was tragic. It was tragic because Nguyen Nhat Anh didn't give readers a happy ending, but it was more tragic because of the choices the characters made - choices that defy logic (hence the tableflip).
That said, I think this is an important story. A story that illustrates how one can get really consumed in feelings, and the choices one makes can have a deep, lasting impact on others, sometimes for the rest of their lives.

I am not a fan of NNA. Personally, his storyline usually doesn't touch my feeling, it 's boring and safe. But I highly appreciate his writing style, he exclusively creates a combination of bitness and sweetness, all-ages story. Maybe, I am a picky person who tries hard to find something more profound. The senses appearing through his language description such as Vietnam village, humans, and traditional culture are very beautiful and real as much as make us feel like we daily meet it somewhere. "Mat biec" is not an exception. The story is about an unresponded-love, the boy meets a girl with "dreamy eyes" since their childhood. And he still keeps this untold-love inside, after 20 years later, and witnesses the girl becomes a woman and a single mom. Even though I just have read it because of the incoming movie. The trailer and soundtracks hit my feeling so harsh. One more time, I fall in love with his writing style, not the contents.

#31122018

Honestly, I had not had a strong inclination for cheesy romantic, so it was not appealing to me at first. However, I decided to give it a chance as this book was one of the most successful books of Nguyen Nhat Anh.
When I closed the book, I had mixed feelings for it, disliking it and falling for it at the same time. I could not stand the content of the book (to be honest). Specifically, I was shocked a little bit when Tra Long fell for Ngan while he was the one who took care of her since she was a child. I felt that it did not follow the sensible logic that Tra Long should respect Ngan as an uncle (or maybe a farther) instead of being in love with him. Moreover, Nguyen Nhat Anh spent too many pages describing the childhood of the protagonists while the scene that Ngan decided to leave Do Do was so short. This bizarre and out of box ending disappointed me because I expected Ngan to straightly deal with the problems instead of giving in and running away without saying a word (yes he left a letter for Tra Long but I was not satisfied) :)
While there were many factors turning me down, I still gave a 5 star for Mat Biec as I was extremely in love with Nguyen Nhat Anh's writing style. He created the story for all ages and it is easy to digest. His writing completely touched my heart. The daily life of Vietnamese people appearing through his language description was light and touching. Nguyen Nhat Anh was such a talented writer who could turned a basic (yet bizarre) storyline into a poignant novel. To me, Mat Biec could be compared to bright-coloured candies for the mind after a day full of anxiety.
I have seen the movies twice and I would love to see it more. The cast, the movie scene, the music were beyond my expectations. I was so impressed with Tran Nghia as he truly captured the feeling of Ngan.
If you have not watched the movies, go for it!

It's kinda sad finishing this book and not getting what I want. I want to male character to get a happy ending, which he clearly didn't have. The building of character, the growth is executed rather badly, so I will not comment much on that. The plot is rather simple, but the flowery writing makes up for it. Overall an easy book to read on rainy days, not too enjoyable to get through all these actions and receive a sad ending.
And yeah, there's a movie based upon this work and I don't think I'm gonna watch it anyway.

** spoiler alert ** A mixture of fiction and literature?!
All character traits made me angry when I just finished the story.
Ngan - the male protagonist is an unreal figure. He sacrificed everything for what he called love, an untold and unresponding love for Ha Lan. Despite bitter experience, his love remained unchanged and in the end, he left Tra Long - Ha Lanâ€™s daughter who was tried to heal his broken heart by her unconditional love.
It might be fine if others are also built with impracticable character like Ngan. But itâ€™s not. Ha Lan was questionable with both wisdom to take advantage of Ngan knowing his feeling and stupidity to not avoid Dung - a f guy. Tra Longâ€™s appearance and her emotion to Ngan made me consider it as incest situation. And it seem like a young adult who couldnâ€™t decide exactly her own life have to pay for her motherâ€™s owe. While this mother was trying to date other guy.
But when I calm down to think about the books, I like the way NNA describes the beauty old day in villages, and the temptation of city lights. Itâ€™s good.
And the film scene is gorgeous!

** spoiler alert ** Summary:
The book about the unconditional, endless, unfathomable love of a boy for a girl. Yet, It does not turn out euphorically. It all starts with the innocent and eventful childhoods of both the protagonist and his lover. They went to the same primary school, sit next to each other for the entirety of it, then went to the same secondary school and ended up at different high schools. Our miserable protagonist has perpetually had a mountainous rush for his childhood friend. Got into countless fights just to get a dropped fruit for his crush,... Unfortunately, she did not any feeling even just a mild one for him. Instead, she fell for his reckless, unfaithful cousin and got pregnant. Eventually, the kid she bore was single-handedly raised by the miserable protagonist, she finally got married to a third man she had ever dated. Our protagonist was initially thought to end up with the daughter of his lover (ye, it does sound kinda bizarre). Surprisingly, he realized the daughter was just some sort of a replacement for her mother thus deciding to flee the absolutely pathetic scene. What a shame for everyone in the story.
Then comes my review
It's heart-breaking, depressing yet so pathetic. By pathetic, I mean the main character is truly pathetic. But who am I to judge nonetheless? People can get even blinders when it comes to love. He is merely just yet another victim of infatuated love. He literally fell for someone and eternally trapped into the hole he fell in. Knowing that his love will never be returned, he persisted in tremendously love that person. What a pity! Well, in short, definitely recommend this one to the others but I certainly would not say that this is the best romantic novel I have ever read.

** spoiler alert ** Painful Nostalgia
My teacher gave me this book when I left for America and I'm honestly surprised and so in love with it. This story at its core is a coming of age story, we follow Chuong, a city boy who has to spend the summer in the countryside of Vietnam with his aunt and cousins. Over the course of this book, the protagonist runs into some misfits, have some small adventures, and learn some important life lessons, there is an element of romance as well. Now for me, the book hits me really hard because I can relate so much to it, it reminded of my life before I had to move to America, at the end of the book I almost teared up because it gave me so much nostalgia and when I closed it I was just left with an empty feeling. Overall, I recommend it. Now I'm going to go into more details so spoilers I guess. As much as I love the book I don't really like Chuong, from the start of the book to halfway through I didn't really like him, he can sometimes be stupid, immature, and bratty but it's a coming of age story so at the end you do see him acting more mature. It's not only a coming of age story but also a story about young love, while Chuong is enjoying his summer he met a soft-spoken girl named Them, Chuong, of course, fell for her but it seems very one-sided. Because of this romance element that also contributed to the feeling of emptiness and sorrow at the end of the book for me. Them is engaged to someone else already, this revelation hit Chuong like a truck, but instead of acting selfish or just being childish he just put on a smile, gave her a goodbye gift and go back to the busy city. This just made my heart sank, I was speechless, so I just put the book down and just sat for a while as so many emotions were rushing through me. I truly felt empty.

" Yellow Flowers on the Green Grass " is one of the best novels that I particularly enjoy. It is written by the famous author Nguyen Nhat Anh . At the first time reading, I was very impressed with the way story telling. The story portraying love about a family and childhood of each. Tuong is an innocent and lovelyboy while his brother Thieu is curely selfish. A side from brother hood filled with love , hate , regret and atonement ,.... also about friendship . There are fight, interesting kid's game , dreams with the images to become a princess and their first crush . Childhood memory of children living in a poor villages, there by reminding us of humon morality . A story as pure as the driven snow , recall our childhood , and it can also a ticket to help us return to our childhood. This book is great , I think you should read once in your life .

Great book to return childhood. Short stories let my soul out of stress and have relax minutes. Through some stories, I can see many characters with different and unique personality:
+ Tuong - a younger brother has a bright and openly soul, always admire and love his brother although Thieu often has bad action with him. Tuong is not good at studying but really loves reading books.
+ Beautiful love between Uncle Dan and Sis Vinh help us have more belief in real love. They try to pass all challenges to get back together.
+ Wide love of father for mother and Man.
+ Uncle Tam Tang sacrifice himself to help his daughter having wonderful time when living.
+ Thieu - a boy dare to face with not-good thing.
...
This book opens and deletes hidden space in our soul. It helps us having more views about family and we can recognize that no where is best as family. Parents can sacrifice for better life of their children. Younger can sacrifice for his brother that he can study well.
Although parents don't let us know they love us outside but they show it in another way, in soul.

This is a story about the life, poor childhood of each character in the story.
The book consists of 81 short chapters and each chapter is a story about life, about love, friendship, brotherhood ...
Before the first chapter, Nguyen Nhat Anh wrote two verses "Sitting silently in the wind listening to the night
suddenly saw yellow flowers on the green grass "
It was just two sentences but it was enough to make me quickly turn the page to begin into the first pages. With this long story, Nguyen Nhat Anh has told us about moral lessons, humanities and first careless love.
So welcome to you to read and feel a beautiful, sweet and tormented childhood that everyone has experienced in "Yellow flowers on the green grass".

Overall, if you want to have something to relax, you maybe like this book.

Nguyen Nhat Anh is that man, that genius, the icon of my our country's literature. Every new book of him always outsold the previous ones, so I always feel the hype and the urge to read whenever a new work of him is published. Reading this book in a morning made me understand the hype (like every time before when I read his new releases). Stringed from the story of 4 innocent friends at the age of eight with all kinds of mischief: Mui, Hai, Tun and Ti. Through each chapter, we see the author through the character of Mui to think about the world of children and the adult world with all the obsessions such as time, money, love, marriage, family, death. . And thanks to adults, children are always protected and loved to have childhood memories filled with pure laughter.
"Thank adults" to help me get back to my eight-year-old memories again, I hope you will be happy to hold this book in your hand as well.

This is a story innocent student age, full of laughter and no shortage of jokes, playful.
With a clear writing style, when he wrote about the student, it makes many readers from kid to adult have been fascinated and excited when they read books of Nguyen Nhat Anh. The book has 21 short chapters and each chapter is a story about class, friends, about "mischievous boy" Quynh with strange ears that makes me gobble up those short stories and sympathize with him when he gets people who joke and bully but can only fight silently. Reading about his quiet love for Nga (who always defended him when he was bullied) I became more interested in reading.
Nguyen Nhat Anh has shown us a beautiful friendship, although that friendship does not become a bright love, but what they have given for each other which is actually far more precious. So guys, welcome to you to read and feel a friendship, a touching story in "he Mischievous Boy".

Bong Bong Len Troi (rising balloons) by Nguyen Nhat Anh describes a family of kindness and decency, of sacrifice and share that every member has for each other. The book also shows the restless fight against poverty, prejudice and discrimination and the dream for a brighter future of Thuong and Tai Khon.
Thuong's family gets into great difficulty after the death of his father, who helps save a passerby woman from an armed robber and consequently dies from a gunshot. Thuong's Mom is a poor high school math teacher who works days and nights but can hardly make ends meet to raise her two children Thuong, a 11 grader and Nhi, a teen school girl. Because of continuous hard work, she suffers from coughing and pneumonia from time to time.
Thuong loves his mom dearly. He feels miserable seeing his mom's health degrading, so he decides to do something to lighten her loads. Secretly, Thuong stays up late to grade his Mum's students' math papers, though he unavoidably makes some silly mistakes that make his mum doubtful. Thuong fails but he doesn't give up. One time he accidentally meets one of his father's friend who is selling Keo Keo ( a kind of sticky candy) and persuades the man to let him try doing so. Lying to his mom that he has tutor classes, he cycles to a primary school every afternoon and sells his candy. This is where Thuong has a new friend called Tai Khon, who sells balloons.
Tai Khon's family is poor. She doesn't go to school properly but attends evening classes to pursue knowledge. Despite her misfortune, she is lovely and positive, which inspires Thuong to overcome his own financial troubles. Between the two grows a precious and dear friendship which supports them to go though their dark times. Sometimes when it is raining and nobody wants balloons, Tai Khong invites Thuong to fly the colorful balloons up in the sky making wishes for themselves. She convinces Thuong that the balloons carry their wishes and dreams and make them a reality.
One day when Thuong is selling his candy as usual, Nhi - one of his classmates- sees him by chance and is taken by surprise. Interestingly, Nhi wants to help Thuong by offering him to tutor her instead of selling candy. Thuong feels offended but soon realizes that Nhi has a golden heart . However he refuses to tutor the rich kid and continues his job as a candy seller. On Nhi's birthday, upon her request for his candy, he takes it to her birthday party and treat her friends with it. Seeing her brother's discrimination, he leaves the party secretly. Although Nhi disagrees with her brother's attitude, she tries to remain Thuong's good friend.
Coming home from the party, Thuong sees Tai Khon visiting his Mum. He soon finds out that Tai Khon is one of his Mum's favourite students from her evening classes who is courageous and intelligent though coming from a very disadvantaged. Never before has Thuong felt such a strong admiration for the little girl.
The story ends with Thuong being hospitalized and taken care of by his Mum, his sister, and Tai Khon. It turns out that he saves Nhi's brother from being robbed, just like the way his father does before. This accident reconciles the doubt, misunderstanding and discrimination that Nhi's brother once places upon Thuong and bonds the love between his family and friends. Such a happy ending.
This is a very simple but loving book by Nguyen Nhat Anh, my favourite author. His book has shown me that no matter what happens in life, kindness always wins and connects people, helping build connected and strong families, community and society. He makes me believe that there are lots of kind and decent people out there that make our life worth living.
